8689813283:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\n

1. Website content issues have terrible timing

\n

Unnoticed issues become emergencies at the worst possible times, and can force you to drop everything else you’re doing to take care of them.

\n

Let’s set the stage:  You’re working feverishly on the upcoming website redesign project due next week, and for a brief moment you actually start to see a light at the end of the tunnel. The late nights substituting caffeine for sleep are starting to create something that looks like it could satisfy every department’s fickle demands.  A few more days of this and people might actually be smiling when you launch.

\n

Then your horrible, awful phone rings.

\n

It’s the VP of something-or-other, and they’re furious at you personally because their nephew hit a broken link while trying to apply for an internship. They want the link fixed immediately, a full report on how many people the broken link affected, an office-wide email explaining the situation, and daily updates on what you’re doing to make the website error free.

\n

So much for a happy website launch.

\n

2. When it rains, it pours

\n

If the situation above reminds you of some repressed memories, you know that these kinds of things snowball. If it doesn’t, I’d like to congratulate you on your recent college graduation.

\n

After the humiliating email to the office, everyone suddenly becomes an amateur treasure hunter, trolling the website with their metal detectors for buried typos. Your inbox fills up with, “I think there should be a comma here,” and “shouldn’t this be a semicolon?”

\n

Each email saps your time because if you ignore it and someone with an acronym for a job title finds out, you’re going to be in a world of hurt. If you were able to remove your nose from the grindstone, you’d see your website redesign project collecting dust and the light at the end of the tunnel fading to black.

\n

[Whoa, that was super dramatic! There’s a light at the end of this blog - just read a little further and don’t answer your phone.]

\n

3. Stress kills

\n

Neat-o fact: stress is really bad for you.

\n

Aside from feeling really unfun, stress can cause a host of health problems, poor performance and burnout. The health problems are bad enough, but poor performance and burnout means more treasure hunters, which causes more stress. Like Lance Armstrong’s doping debacle, it’s a cyclical problem.

\n

Fortunately it’s also an entirely treatable problem, which brings us to the happy, sun-shiny light at the end of this blog:

\n

How to prevent website induced stress

\n

I know what you’re thinking: “sounds scary, but I still don’t have time to do anything more than what’s on my plate right now.”  The good news is you don’t have to!

\n

Automation and delegation are your two new best friends. You can automate the discovery of broken links, misspellings, web accessibility issues, and a bunch of other things with tools like Siteimprove, and even streamline the process for fixing them.  Once they’ve been identified, you can delegate responsibility for fixing them to the people responsible for creating them automatically.

\n

As the old saying goes, “many hands make light work of irate nepotistic vice presidents.”

\n

If this situation had involved automated discovery and delegation tools, it could have gone very differently.  Instead of getting blindsided in the 11th hour and led through the office in stocks and chains, the issue could have been caught before it became a problem, or you could have been aware of it and prepared to give an account:

\n

“Yes, unfortunately the broken link is a known issue that we’re currently working to fix. The link has been clicked a total of three times, and is currently assigned to [editor], who usually fixes them within 24 hours. I’ll contact [editor] immediately to alert them to the top priority of this issue.”

\n

It sure is bright at the end of the tunnel.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689825073:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nThe Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content \n

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\n
\n

The same philosophy can serve as a model for creating new content or assessing existing content. Content that successfully meets the higher-level, strategic needs of the audience and the business also needs to succeed on the lower levels shown above. Each level in this hierarchy will probably have different degrees of priority depending on whether the content is a blog post, a video, news release, etc.

\n

Following Maslow’s lead, the description of this pyramid starts at the ground level and works up from there. It’s worth noting that these are building blocks, and NOT intended to represent a linear process. You need to consider each of these levels before, during, and after you create content (or as you assess existing content).

\n

1. Accurate

\n

This is the foundational baseline, the food/water/shelter level for content.

\n
    \n
  • Is it factually accurate?
    • \n
  • Is it grammatically correct and free of typos?
    • \n
  • Has it been entered into the CMS correctly?
    • \n
  • Do the links work?
    • \n
  • Does it have metadata?
    • \n
\n

The good news is that there are tools that can help with this. Many content management systems include spell-check tools, and there are also external tools (such as Siteimprove) that do this. In fact, the benefit of using tools for these foundational elements is that the people involved in creating and managing the content can focus on the remaining aspects of the content hierarchy.

\n

2. Necessary

\n

This addresses whether the content needs to exist at all.

\n
    \n
  • Is this content unique on the site? Unique on the Web?
    • \n
  • Is it topical and timely?
    • \n
  • Is it relevant to the audience?
    • \n
  • Is it appropriate for the business to share?
    • \n
  • Is it required for the audience to know?
    • \n
\n

3. Authentic

\n

This addresses whether the content is (and should be) from our organization. For some organizations, this will consist only of original information; for others, their content will include analysis of others’ information (known as “curation”).

\n
    \n
  • If it is original content, is it created in our brand voice?
    • \n
  • If it is curated content, is the original source attributed and our analysis clearly identified?
    • \n
  • If it contains an executive byline, was it actually written by that person?
    • \n
  • Are we providing the context/analysis/perspective that only we can offer and that will help our audience use the information?
    • \n
\n

4. Effective

\n

This is about promotion and measurement.

\n
    \n
  • Does the audience know that this content exists?
    • \n
  • Do other internal content creators know about it?
    • \n
  • What is the size of the target audience?
    • \n
  • Do we have a goal and a call-to-action for this content?
    • \n
  • Do we have a plan for achieving that goal? (Editorial calendar for promotions on our site, on social media, in our e-newsletters, etc.)
    • \n
  • Will we measure how many people have seen/heard/used this content? Will we know who they are?
    • \n
\n

5. Strategic

\n

This is the pinnacle of the consideration pyramid. It addresses why the organization is creating and publishing this content now.

\n
    \n
  • What business goals does this content help achieve?
    • \n
  • What user needs does this content meet?
    • \n
  • Does it have a lifecycle for reviewing/renewing/expiring it?
    • \n
  • What do we expect this content to help us accomplish?
    • \n
\n

Organizations, make a decision to publish content or keep it online only when it works on all five of these levels. Content that works at the highest level is truly ready to succeed.

\n

Bio:

\n

Hilary Marsh is chief strategist and principal at Content Company, a Chicago-based content strategy consultancy. Thanks to @ContentScotland, @Content1st, @robram, @MxDEJ, and @GetSprkd for their input.

\n

\n5 Ways to Make Your Mobile Website Not Stink\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/3/13 2:14 AM\n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

\n
\n
\n

Cut the Crap

\n

Not all website content will be able to effectively fit onto a mobile site, so it’s essential to reduce the amount of content displayed. When deciding what to include, focus on only the most important content and features. This may include information such as contact details, services offered and prices. Additional information such as customer testimonials may be nice to include but isn’t absolutely necessary. Mobile websites should be simple to read and easy to navigate. Remember when it comes to your mobile site less will always be more.

\n

Stay Single

\n

Normal sized web pages overwhelmingly do not suit mobile platforms. When they load, the page ends up being so small that text is unreadable, and forces the user to zoom in to read content. Not only does this add another step to the user journey but it also makes for a navigation nightmare – especially with certain types of phones. Instead, mobile websites should employ the use of single column pages that take up the entire width of the screen. Then depending on how much content you include, make sure that content loads downwards rather than across, as this will make scrolling easier.

\n

Reduce Requirements

\n

Mobile phones have come a long way since the brick handset most of us first had, yet entering large blocks of text using mobile keyboards still remains difficult. While physical QWERTY keyboards tend to be the easiest to use, followed by touchscreen QWERTY keyboards, and then the traditional 12 button physical 12 alphanumeric keypads, all have limitations. Users are much more likely to make mistakes when using mobile keyboards, and are therefore significantly slower - all of which can ruin the user experience. Instead, text entry requirements should be reduced. This can be done a variety of ways, such as offering users the opportunity to use stored details or asking users to enter a pin instead of a password.

\n

Use a Smart Touch

\n

In many countries including the US and the UK, smartphones account for the majority of mobile usage, so it’s essential that your mobile website is optimized for them. Smartphone screens will vary, and may be touch or have more traditional trackball, joystick or directional keys. Your design should be suited to both. The most common navigation difficulty for those using smartphones to surf the web is clicking on the often-small text links accurately. Our fingers tend to fail us, and when links are close together it’s easy to tap the wrong one. Avoid using links for important calls to action, and instead consider using design calls such as thick rows that span the width of the screen or large square boxes that can be easily tapped.

\n

Automate the Advantage  

\n

While desktops and laptops may be easier for web browsing, many smartphones do have advantages over their full-sized cousins – mainly their inbuilt functionality that allows users to bypass manual steps. To ensure your mobile website utilizes these inbuilt functionalities consider the following options:

\n
    \n
  • Allow users to automatically ring a number when they tap or click a phone number.
    • \n
  • Give users the option to select an address and have it automatically open on their mobile phone’s map app.
    • \n
  • Utilize inbuilt GPS systems to help users easily find the things they want nearby.
    • \n
\n

For many more tips on how to improve your website and increase accessibility check out our previous blog post ‘13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time’.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nCreate an annual search cycle\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n\n
\n

We recommend that you look at the most popular search terms on your website at least once a month, and then perform those searches yourself to see if the results are useful and up to date.

\n

When creating an annual search cycle, the check is based on the search terms used in the past month. Some of them may be seasonal and might not be relevant until next year, (e.g. 4th of July related searches spike in June, but end suddenly come July 5th) so it's important that you document them clearly for later use.

\n

User information needs vary during the year, but search patterns typically stay the same - allowing you to predict likely search terms next year.  Therefore, we recommend that you put together an annual cycle to show an overview of which search terms are being used during each period.

\n

Try these steps as a guide towards initiating your annual cycle in search:

\n
    \n
  • Examine the most popular search terms for each month
    • \n
  • Fill terms into an Excel table where you place the months side by side. It's best to remove plural endings, synonyms, etc.
    • \n
  • Sort the terms alphabetically for each month. This will create an overview and help you distinguish between the terms to see if they appear in most months, or only in a few months.
    • \n
  • Ensure terms are easily identifiable which are specific to that month/or quarter.
    • \n
\n

Having this overview allows you to supplement your monthly/quarterly check of search terms with a check of the terms that are expected to be relevant next month/quarter. With a good internal search engine program, you can create search term rules and quick links if the results for a search are not excellent. Doing this helps ensure that the users find exactly what they're looking for, and keeps your content up to date, ready for SEO, and accessible.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718691523:\n\n\n\n\n\nGet inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nGet inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website \n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n\n
\n

There is a wide variety of opportunities to use web analytics to help you create your new website. It can be anything from documenting your results to make your case for management to allocate the resources needed, to analysis that supports the graphical design and target group analysis that can be used to develop user profiles of the visitors.

\n

But basically there are two phases when we talk about web analytics in connection with the re-design and development of new website: a pre-launch phase and a post-launch phase.

\n

Phase 1: Pre-Launch

\n

The pre-launch phase is where web analytics should be implemented in the project as early as possible to give you strategic advantages by having access to information about how visitors use your existing website.

\n

By using web analytics to understand how visitors use your existing website when you're doing your initial research for your new website, you ensure that you right from the start is supporting the redesign or new web project with relevant data.

\n

Specifically, it can provide answers to essential questions that anyone who has a website should know. Questions like:

\n
    \n
  • Who are our users?
    • \n
  • What content on our current website do they look at?
    • \n
  • How do they end up on our current website?
    • \n
  • What do they do/where do they go when they visit the website?
    • \n
  • What feedback have we received from our users?
    • \n
\n

Knowing the geographic location of your users, their technical specifications, and whether they use computers or mobile devices when visiting your website will give you a clearer picture of your users and where to focus your efforts. It isn't realistic to expect to have complete answers for all the questions above, but combined with other information such as a survey the picture of the users' profiles is much sharper.

\n

Combine the above with an analysis of the most popular content (and the least popular), how users are finding the website, the users' behavior and the most used routes on the website, and you have a strong foundation to support and develop the web strategy for its re-design/new website.

\n

Phase 2: Post-Launch

\n

After the launch of your new website/redesign, you must ensure the continuous optimization of your website by implementing a lasting workflow enabling the constant measuring, analyzing and optimizing of your website. This process must be an iterative process where you are constantly working to optimize the user experience for your visitors.

\n

In order to work iteratively to optimize and analyze your new website, you need to have access to the correct Key Performance Indicators (KPI's), measurements, and a full dataset available. This brings us back to the pre-launch phase again.

\n

During the planning and development in the pre-launch phase you should ensure you have implemented your web analytics tool properly. At the same time, it's important to make sure you have developed your website in a way that makes it possible to extract the data needed to work with the continuous optimization of the website. A proper set-up from the start does not cost that much extra time, but will certainly pay off in the long run.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n\n
\n

\n

\nWeb Governance Policies and Procedures\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n12/5/12 3:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Where would an employee go with questions to how a specific task is done on your website?

\n
\n\n
\n

In our previous blog posts about web governance, we give a broad introduction to the topic of web governance as well as a look into coupling web governance with specific topics. In this post I'll talk about web governance policies and procedures.

\n

Why and how

\n

In my blog post about roles and responsibilities in web governance I looked at the Who (roles) and What (responsibilities). Web governance policies answers why you should (and why you shouldn't) do web tasks in a specific way and is comprised of rules that guide the decision making process. Procedures describe how specific web tasks are done, so you can be sure you have a uniform and high quality approach to your website.

\n

Policies and procedures are important because they set the frame for how your web team should work. If an employee has a question to how a task on your website is done, policies and procedure should be the first place to look.

\n

What are policies?

\n

Web governance policies are rules that guide the day-to-day work of your web team and ensure that any laws governing your websites are kept. If there is a reason for doing things in a specific way in relation to your web presence, you should have a policy for it. Policies can cover accessibility compliance, compliance with other rules, laws and standards, social media usage, content review and much more.

\n

Here are a few examples of policies:

\n
    \n
  • When publishing new content to the company website, the content should be reviewed for compliance with the corporate tone-of-voice guidelines.
    • \n
  • All pages on the website must contain a link to our privacy policy.
    • \n
  • When linking to or attaching documents to web pages, these must be uploaded in PDF file format.
    • \n
  • All content on the website should be available in at least English, as this is our corporate language.
    • \n
\n

What are procedures?

\n

Web governance procedures are guidelines that tell you exactly how to do a specific task, to ensure uniformity in the web presence. If you have a web task you want done in the same way, every time it is done, make a procedure for it. Procedures include usage of web analytics, organization of articles, styling and so on.

\n

Here are a few examples of procedures:

\n
    \n
  • Upon uploading a new picture to the media library, you must click on the tab 'crop' and make sure that crops for thumbnails, highlights and sidebars exists.
    • \n
  • When writing a blog post for the corporate blog you must\n
      \n
    • Include all the elements described in the document 'how to write for the company blog.'
      • \n
    • Send the document to the marketing manager for review.
      • \n
    • Send the reviewed document to the UK and DK marketing managers for translation.
      • \n
    • Search statistics must be analyzed on the first Monday of every month in accordance with the document 'Internal search maintenance.'
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

Getting started with policies and procedures

\n

When implementing web governance in your organization it is a great idea to include all members of the web team in the forming of policies and procedures. They probably already follow some unwritten rules of their own, so by starting out with writing these down you'll already have a lot of the work done, while your employees will feel ownership of the policies and procedures.

\n

To make your policies and procedures work, you'll have to make sure they are enforced. A nice way of doing this is to have training sessions where employees get to work with the procedures and can ask questions if needed. A more informal way could be encouraging employees to remind each other of the policies and procedures once in a while.

\n

If you already have implemented a well-functioning web governance with clear roles and responsibilities, and policies and procedures, then I would love to hear from you either in the comments or by email. We would love to hear about you experiences.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8735719503:\n\n\n\n\n\nAre You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nAre You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n\n

If you’re already feeling a little overwhelmed, don’t worry, I’ll be discussing more specific examples for working with tables on your webpages in my free on-demand webinar, which you can download at the end of this blog.

\n

Layout Tables vs. Data Tables

\n

Tables have been used for page layout since the early days of the Web. Due to advancements in both W3C recommendations and coding capabilities, table layouts are becoming another distant memory, as they may cause considerable accessibility problems. The presentation and layout of web page elements can and should be controlled through appropriate cascading style sheets (CSS) and tables should be used to display data only.

\n

Use the Simplest Table Possible

\n

Simple Tables

\n

A simple table basically means that there is only one header row and one header column in the table. A header specifies the type of information in the row/column. There are no merged cells within a simple table. Once we have merged cells, we need to approach the table as a complex table, which have different coding considerations. It may even be preferable to create more than one simple table instead of using a complex table.

\n

Complex Tables

\n

Sometimes, complex tables are required. Some data tables may require more than one level of row and/or column heading. Most people will not find this a problem; visually the table is logical. However, Assistive Technology, like screen readers, will need very specific instructions to correlate these extra levels of headings to the information contained in the data cells.

\n

Marking Up Tables

\n

The very first step toward creating an accessible data table is to define row and column headers. This is easy enough to do. In the markup, the <td> tag is used for table data cells and the <th> tag is used for table header cells.

\n

Simply changing the appropriate <td> tags to <th> tags signifies that the information within the cell is different from the information that still sits in a <td> cell. The location of the cell does not change. Now before you say, “That was easy,” be aware that this is just the first part of making that simple table accessible. It gets a little more complicated, but not too complicated. I promise.

\n

Associate Data Cells with Appropriate Headers

\n

Now that we've created headers, we need to associate the cells with the appropriate headers. There are two ways to associate data cells with their headers.

\n

The Scope Attribute

\n

The scope attribute tells the browser and screen reader that everything under the column is related to the header at the top, and everything to the right of the row header is related to that header. By specifying the “col” or “row” attribute in addition to the scope attribute, you’ve tied that column or row to the correct header. A screen reader now has the instructions it needs to present the table correctly.

\n

Headers and ID Attributes

\n

Another way to accomplish this is to use the headers and ID attributes.

\n

This method is NOT recommended for simple tables, but may be useful in complex tables. The headers and ID method should only be used when there is more than one logical level in a table, and when it is necessary to link more than two headers with a data cell. Stick with the scope attribute unless your table is more complex and the scope attribute will not do the trick.

\n

Proportional Sizing

\n

Use proportional table sizing rather than absolute or fixed-pixel sizing. Let the browser window determine the width of the table whenever possible. By establishing a fixed width on a table, you are not allowing the table to flow into the viewport area available. Luckily, this is becoming a more standard practice now that we are planning and implementing responsive website layouts.

\n

Other Table Markups

\n

<caption> Tags

\n

Tables should have some sort of identifying title or caption to them. Using the <caption> tag can do this, and you can add the <caption> tag right after the opening <table> tag. It is not absolutely necessary to have <caption> tags on every data table for the sake of accessibility, but it is still a good practice. And of course all of these additional attributes and tags can be styled appropriately with your cascading style sheets.

\n

Summary Attribute

\n

The summary attribute is not a requirement for simple tables, but can increase the comprehension of more complex tables for people using screen readers. A good summary can highlight the important elements of a table, and help the user to know what data can be found in the table. A good practice is to only use table summaries when they do what they were designed to do: summarize complex data.

\n

Want to learn more about Accessible Tables?

\n

There are other more complex methods of marking up tables than those discussed here. Please download the on-demand webinar below for a more hands-on explanation of coding tables. The webinar will be a useful guide to understanding some of the different techniques for making tables accessible. I’ll show code examples and discuss:

\n
    \n
  • Simple tables
    • \n
  • Complex tables
    • \n
  • The correct attributes to make a table accessible
    • \n
  • Proportional Sizing
    • \n
  • Additional Table code attributes
    • \n
\n

 

\n

\n \n \n  

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8692487803:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Prepare for a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

How to Prepare for a Website Redesign

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Make sure your next redesign begins on solid footing

\n

Your website is the most important marketing tool you have, and you need it to look its best. This eBook will help you ask the right questions and check your blind spots as you begin your next website redesign project.

\n

This eBook will show you how to:

\n
    \n
  • Begin planning your redesign with data from your analytics software
    • \n
  • Ensure your website is accessibility compliant
    • \n
  • Predict users’ needs based on search statistics
    • \n
  • Avoid common pitfalls during the redesign process
    • \n
  • Choose an SEO-friendly mobile website design
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8689776513:\n\n\n\n\n\n3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\n

1. Define the purpose of your redesign

\n

The first step to a successful website redesign is to ask the question “Why are we doing a redesign?” That might sound obvious, but you’d be surprised how many websites get redesigned without anyone creating a solid answer to that question. Your gut instinct that the website is ugly, or the user experience is underperforming may be accurate, but without further exploration your next redesign will likely be no better. Use data, not your gut, to add definition to the question “why.”

\n

You should structure each redesign goal in three layers:

\n
    \n
  1. What part of the website specifically is underperforming, and how does it tie into the goal of your website?
    2. \n
  2. Redefine the goal based on the data you’ve collected
    3. \n
  3. Determine why this goal is important to your organization
    4. \n
\n

2. Use data for decision making and planning

\n

Data is extremely useful for helping us to ask the right questions – it doesn’t provide the answers! You need to create experiments to test theories on why the data shows what it does.

\n

Use the data to:

\n
    \n
  • Identify the problems
    • \n
  • Refine your understanding of those problems
    • \n
  • Define questions that will lead to solutions to the problems
    • \n
\n

Now that you’ve formulated questions based on hard data, use your intuition to make educated guesses as to the answers to the questions provided by your data, and then test your hypothesis with experiments.

\n

3. Web accessibility matters

\n

Web accessibility is the inclusive practice of making websites usable by people of all abilities and disabilities. Without intentional effort, you may exclude some users from being able to properly use the new website you’ve spent so much energy creating.

\n

Making your website accessible has its benefits:

\n
    \n
  • Social responsibility (it’s the right thing to do)
    • \n
  • Larger customer base (studies show that 20% of the US population claims a disability)
    • \n
  • Efficient Code (search engines and users with disabilities have many characteristics in common)
    • \n
\n

Want to learn more about preparing for a website redesign? Check out our on-demand webinar, “How to Prepare for a Website Redesign.”

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

Web Quality Assurance Check Report

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Managing websites can be tricky, especially the more pages it has, and the more people responsible for its content. 

\n

Want to see a free report of broken links and misspellings on your website?
Fill out the form to the right and we'll get started!

\n\n

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through: 

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Web Quality Assurance

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Web Accessibility

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Web Analytics

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Search Engine Optimization Analysis

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Web Performance Alerts

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n 8689783783:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n\n
\n

Stop Dropping and Rolling

\n

The first step is often the hardest, and this is no exception: if you want to be proactive you absolutely, positively have to stop putting out fires.

\n

I know, I know.  This isn’t a novel suggestion you’ve never thought of before, it’s probably the first thing you’d wish for if you stumbled upon a magic lamp.  Here’s another thing you probably already know: There’s a good chance the only way you’ll ever be able to do it is by taking a stand with your boss and asking him/her to hold off on bringing you little details like they’re emergencies.

\n

If you can’t get a moment’s peace to plan ahead, you’ll be stuck fighting fires for the rest of your life. That’s bad for you and bad for your organization, because you’re way less effective at doing the things they’ve hired you to do when you’re running around with your hair on fire.

\n

There are lots of great articles on the web about how to approach your boss, so I won’t go into too much detail on the specifics of how to do it. Make sure you have a private discussion with your boss about how to reach a mutual goal, instead of confronting them in a meeting. Plan what you’re going to say ahead of time, and make sure you speak in terms that matter to them, keeping the company as the focus. How much more of the company’s objectives could you accomplish if you weren’t constantly putting out fires? How can you work together to lessen the flow of emergencies to make that happen?

\n

It’s a scary conversation to initiate, but if you want to be proactive it’s 100% necessary.

\n

Make Yourself Flame Retardant

\n

Now that you’ve talked to your boss and reached an agreement on stopping or slowing the fires, it’s time to start working ahead. If you don’t have written goals and objectives for your website, you need to sit down with your boss and make them. Then, define your Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and build goals based on them.

\n

The most important thing to consider when making metrics for your website is mapping them back to business goals. A metric that doesn’t match company or department goals will be easily overridden by the next “emergency” and won’t protect you from firefighting in the future.

\n

Once you’ve set your goals and KPIs, all your tasks should explicitly support them.  Keep an updated list of all your tasks, which goals they support, and what priority level they are. The next time your boss comes to you with another fire to put out, show them your task list and what you’re currently working on, and ask them to prioritize the fire. If your goals and KPIs are clearly tied to the company/department’s goals and you explain that putting out this fire will delay your other objectives, chances are they’ll rethink the importance level of the new task. This is especially true if you’ve already had a productive discussion about the detriment to your productivity posed by firefighting.

\n

However, some level of firefighting will always be a part of every job, which is why this section is titled “Make Yourself Flame Retardant” instead of “Make Yourself Fireproof.” Be flexible to the needs of your boss, and understand that they may be coming to you due to pressure from the people above them. They might appreciate the assistance so much, they’ll let you do your job!

\n

Get tips and best practices for your next website redesign project:

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nWhy Content Governance Drives Engagement\n

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n

The Smithsonian is going for a hipper, more modern feel to their language, communications and the feel of their overall brand. This makes sense, considering they cater to 30 million people every year, who want to learn about varied topics, including natural history, science, design, culture and the like.

\n

The use of the word stash might be different for the Smithsonian and it brings to mind something we all need to think about, which is content governance. Let’s examine why governance is vital to an overall content strategy.

\n

Is your content:

\n
    \n
  • Unorganized?
    • \n
  • Lacking a clear voice?
    • \n
  • Consistently confusing to customers?
    • \n
\n

Then you should be interested in content governance. (Note: We are specifically speaking of content governance, and not web governance, which mandates consistency across content and technology and design)

\n

What is Content Governance?

\n

Content governance is the day-to-day detailed management of content delivery and style, as well as the long-term execution of content strategy tactics. Think of content governance as an overall structure that:

\n
    \n
  • Determines priorities
    • \n
  • Provides detailed guidelines and standards on how content should look, behave, and interact with your customers
    • \n
  • Assigns ownership to people within the organization, so they can make strategic decisions about content
    • \n
\n

Governance:

\n
    \n
  • Creates a consistent customer experience across channels
    • \n
  • Avoids content bloat
    • \n
  • Sets internal organizational controls
    • \n
\n

Create a Consistent Customer Experience across Channels

\n

If content is a conversation, then we absolutely must know to whom we are talking, who we are and what we are trying to say. And we must pick a voice and tone, and a vocabulary (think “stash”), that fits in with our brand.

\n

Governance standards help you set a consistent customer experience across all channels. By following them you avoid replicating content, muddying your main messages, and confusing your audiences.

\n

Set Internal Organizational Controls

\n

Governance is also critical in setting internal organizational controls. Most conflict in offices stems from not knowing who is in charge (Most conflict in life stems from the same reason). By setting up a clear governance model for content within an organization, you can set clear internal organizational controls. This avoids the “I’m the one in charge,” arguments that often happen around content and leads you to a home page seven scrolls long.

\n

Therefore, governance is helpful in institutional politics, as well in establishing clear guidance on content ownership and process. The tools involved in content governance may include, among others, content workflows, editorial guidelines, style guides, taxonomies, web content committees, and archiving standards.

\n

In our webinar on March 19th, we will discuss content governance in depth, including:

\n
    \n
  • Why it’s so important to your organization
    • \n
  • Why it drives revenue
    • \n
  • How to sell it to your internal teams so they cultivate a culture of governance
    • \n
  • Governance tools you can institute within the week
    • \n
\n

Watch our on-demand recorded webinar on solving your content challenges and driving revenue and engagement in a thoughtful, consistent manner.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

    • \n
  • Website Redesign Checklist
    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689802503:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhat's up with 'not provided'?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWhat's up with 'not provided'?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\n
\n

The only keywords you will continue to see in Siteimprove SEO and Analytics, are keywords from other search engines like Bing and Yahoo, as well as keywords from Google Adwords ads. It is important to emphasize that this is not just a problem for Siteimprove. All other analysis tools have the same problem - the data will simply no longer exist. Not even in Google Analytics. 

\n

What do we do then?

\n

That is actually a pretty good question, and Siteimprove unfortunately cannot provide data that no longer exists. However, we do have some good advice on how to get an idea of ​​what users are looking at despite [not provided]:

\n
    \n
  • Look at statistics from your internal search in Siteimprove Analytics. Your users might not be using the exact same keywords when searching in Google as they do in your internal search, but at least you get an idea of ​​what topics your users are interested in, and what keywords they typically use. We often see that these are not necessarily the same keywords that you would use or that you think they would use to find your products or services.
    • \n
  • Look at statistics of your most popular entry pages in Siteimprove SEO. Although you can no longer see exactly what keywords users have searched for to get to that page, you can probably make a pretty qualified guess at which keywords they must have used - if you look at the page content and the keywords that are included in the text.
    • \n
  • Look at historical data from Siteimprove Analytics. Even though, in the future, keyword data will not be provided by Google, you will always be able to retrieve historical data in the tool.
    • \n
\n

What is Siteimprove going to do?

\n

Siteimprove will be reviewing the tools in order to address the consequences of the disappearing keyword data. There will be tables and columns that will no longer provide useful information and some of them will be removed completely while others will be adapted to the new situation.

Others will remain as they are, so that you can continue to view historical keyword data.

Last but not least: we will focus on developing new and exciting features to help our customers improve their websites despite [not provided].

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8590094513:\n\n\n\n\n\n8 Deadly Web Analytics Sins\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n
\n

8 Deadly Web Analytics Sins

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox.

\n

However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. These eight sins show how data that looks reliable may not be valid.

\n

 

\n



\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

\n
\n
\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8702982393:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Dollars and Cents of Web Governance\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

\nThe Dollars and Cents of Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\n
\n

Minimizing Costs With Self-Service

\n

Many local governments, service providers, and other organizations utilize self-service to reduce internal costs. This process is commonly referred to as "channel shift." When users can go onto your website and find the information they want, pay bills, and help themselves it frees your staff up to do other important things, saving you time and money.

Banks offer an excellent look at the quantifiable difference that working self-service can make: A study conducted by TowerGroup Estimates found that the average transactional cost of online banking was just $0.20, while the average phone call cost $2.40. Simply by encouraging customers to use the self-service functions of their websites, banks can save millions of dollars per year.

So what if you're not a bank? You probably still have self-service portions of your website. Whether it's hours of operation, your street address, or an FAQ, there's information helping users find what they're looking for. And if they can't find it, they'll call you for assistance - which costs you money. $2.40/phone call adds up pretty quickly.  

\n

Reducing Lost Leads

\n

Colleges and universities live and die by their ability to recruit prospective students. According to a study by Noel-levitz, 20% of all college students report crossing a school off their list of prospective schools because of a bad experience with the website. Simply by having errors and poorly laid out content, colleges and universities risk losing up to 20% of their total prospective students and revenue.

This same principle applies to any organization: For ecommerce sites, one British analysis concluded that the presence of even a single spelling error in an online store can cut sales in half.

\n

Increasing Customer Retention

\n

The following example is from one of our own customers:
In 2012, BOSCH Communications signed on with us and spent the first month of their service fixing the broken links that had inevitably creeped on to their site.  Most of these broken links were within the online content libraries intended to help customers utilize their products and services.

The next month after fixing their broken links, their analytics program showed that the average time spent on their website had increased by 56%. Because they had not made any other significant changes to the website, the web manager attributes the increase to users no longer hitting dead links and giving up their search in frustration.    

\n

'Summing up' Web Governance 

\n

This blog only touches the surface on the added benefits of investing and doing Web Governance right. Although implementing a strategy may appear daunting at first, it really needn't be. There's a great opportunity to give your users what they want and in turn reduce your service costs, particularly if your web governance strategy seeks to leverage present and future developments. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Don't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\nRead More\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance from an SEO Point of View

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Four good ideas on how to find the right keywords

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Show me the money!

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n

\n
\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n\n

Managing your online content marketing efforts requires a dedicated team, relevant strategies, and an understanding of your website’s needs. That’s where Web Governance comes in. A web governance tool will help you to quickly identify the most pressing needs for your website and allow you to build the right team, create the right strategy, and develop a proactive approach to website management. 

\n

What is Content Marketing?

\n

Content marketing is the byproduct of a society that has been saturated with traditional marketing. Where technology once enabled businesses to reach consumers anywhere at any time, it has now allowed those same consumers to skip, block, and altogether ignore your unsolicited marketing advances.

\n

Content marketing is the practice of creating and distributing valuable, relevant, and consistent content in order to attract your target audience. Consumers are more educated and more savvy than ever, so simply telling them what to do or what to buy just won’t fly anymore. Content marketing aims to show them how your organization can provide the product or service that they’re looking for.

\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

Web governance is the byproduct of our Internet dominated world.  Just look at that last sentence, Internet is capitalized because it’s a proper noun now. That’s a reflection of just how important it is to our society, and how much we depend on it as an information sharing and communication platform.

\n

Web governance refers to the systems and practices used to manage your Internet presence. As your presence grows, web governance enables your organization to maintain stability and focus on its online goals.

\n

How They Work Together

\n

Content Consistency

\n

You’ve spent a lot of time and energy (and probably money) creating content that is relevant, useful, and targeted to your audience. If you haven’t done so, just keep reading and pretend that you have, we won’t tell. Over time, new content will be added, old content will need to be updated or removed, and brand standards will evolve. But as your site grows, managing that content becomes more difficult and manually checking every single page becomes physically impossible.

\n

Moving or updating content can lead to broken links, misspellings can slip through the cracks as content is handed off from writers to developers, and legal/regulatory disclaimers will need to be monitored for accuracy. Web governance tools and strategies will help you monitor page content as it changes to ensure quality and consistency on a large scale.

\n

Team Roles & Responsibilities

\n

As your website grows, so too (hopefully) will the team who manages it. This opens the door for two potential and equally frustrating issues- overlapping responsibilities and responsibility gaps. The obvious problems caused by both are bad enough, but the worst part is that they often aren’t noticed until it’s too late.

\n

Having a website governance strategy in place will allow you to identify key tasks and areas of responsibility for the members of your team. This will allow you to minimize errors, improve communication, and maximize your team’s efficiency. Check out Shane Diffily's recent blog to learn more.

\n

Project Prioritization

\n

Managing a huge website with a small team and a smaller budget means adopting a reactive strategy, one where you’re constantly putting out fires and working on whichever project you’re getting harassed about the most. This can lead to a stressful work environment and prevent you from completing the most important projects.

\n

Employing a website governance tool means being able to monitor your website content’s effectiveness, which allows your team to prioritize the projects and areas that need to be addressed, and when. This helps you effectively manage your team, keep key stakeholders updated on the progress you’re making, and defend the decisions you’re making based on factual data.

\n

Employing the proper website governance tools and strategies will help you manage your content, maintain a positive work environment for your team, and ultimately achieve your online goals.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\nWebsite Accessibility and Our Aging Population\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n\n

With age comes the potential for impairments or disabilities that can make it difficult to manage day-to-day activities. One of those activities involves interaction with the Internet, and the devices we use to access it. In this month's webinar, we will address the importance of accessibility issues that affect our older population. These “silver surfers” are engaging the Internet in a variety of ways that they may not have done in the past. Some of those uses include but are not limited to:

\n
    \n
  • Email
    • \n
  • Banking
    • \n
  • Medical Resources
    • \n
  • Travel Resources
    • \n
  • Government Services
    • \n
  • Social Media
    • \n
  • Shopping
    • \n
  • News and Weather
    • \n
\n

How Devices and Technology are changing

\n

Increased connectivity and availability has changed how everyone uses the web. We are more wired than ever before. While many seniors still do not use smart phone technology, tablets and e- book readers are important tools for this group. 

\n

Many seniors have also moved from the hand-me-down computers that one of the kids brought them and set up at Christmas time a few years ago. Gram used to just get pictures via email. Not anymore. She’s now on Facebook, she buys her own e-books on Amazon.com, and was even able to book her own flight to come visit last summer. We may still assist our parents in the purchase process, but more seniors are choosing their own devices based on their own unique needs.

\n

Without getting into statistics, be aware that six in 10 seniors now go online regularly, and that technology has become an essential part of their lives. It's extremely important that older users have their accessibility needs met. This can be done easily through correct coding procedures, browser settings, and in many cases may not require additional assistive technology.

\n

Considerations

\n

When older users are adopting these technologies, they may be faced with a different set of problems while learning to use them. They may deal with issues like physical challenges, conservative attitudes towards the technology, and with so many different kinds of devices available, there could be a steep learning curve for each different operating system and interface.

\n

There is a wide range of disabilities to consider; some may be temporary, some are situational, and some are permanent. Some examples include carpal tunnel surgery (temporary), a noisy room (situational), or a combination of degenerative conditions that may permanently affect sight, hearing, mobility, or cognitive behavior.

\n

Let’s look at some specific examples:

\n
    \n
  • Sight - reduced contrast, color perception, and focus make it difficult to read webpages
    • \n
  • Hearing - difficulty hearing sounds or separating sounds make listening difficult, especially on mobile devices.
    • \n
  • Mobility – the individual may have reduced dexterity or fine motor control, which makes it difficult to use a mouse or difficulty clicking on small link targets.
    • \n
  • Cognitive - these symptoms may include short-term memory loss, unable to concentrate, easily distracted, and difficulty following navigation and finishing online tasks.
    • \n
\n

The Business Case

\n

For both people with and without disabilities, accessible website coding removes these barriers. An accessible site is one that everyone can use and benefit from. Nearly a billion people on earth have some form of disability and that number continues to grow. There is a huge amount of talent, wisdom, skill, and productivity wasted when people with disabilities are unable to participate in the process.

\n

Leadership, marketing, designers, developers, and legal experts all should be aware of building accessibility into the products that people use every day.  The W3C is much attuned to this trend and has a wealth of information available online. These resources include the WAI-AGE project, which gives us a better understanding of the needs of older web users, development of educational materials, and a better overall understanding of this issue.

\n
Want to learn more about accessibility and our aging population?
\n
Download our on-demand webinar for a more in-depth discussion about this crucial
\n
website accessibility topic.
\n
\n

\n \n \n  

\n

Image courtesy of Stuart Miles at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8954268493:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Web Governance Food Pyramid\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
