\n

\nEnsuring the last laugh isn't at your expense\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n

Not only do mistakes increase consumer distrust, studies also show they cost your business thousands, if not millions of dollars.

\n

One sure fire way to irritate customers and lose business is through bad spelling, as online entrepreneur Charles Duncombe so aptly pointed out a few years ago:

\n

After undertaking an analysis of websites that contained poor spelling, he concluded that it was costing UK businesses millions in lost revenue. In one example alone, he measured the revenue per visitor to a British website with a spelling mistake. He found that figures indicated that just one spelling mistake cut online sales in half, but once the mistake was corrected revenue was often twice as high.

\n

One US executive who knows the effects errors can have on a business's reputation is Boyd Savage from Fredrikson & Byron Law Firm. Worried about the time, money, and embarrassment errors were causing, they chose to invest in Siteimprove Quality Assurance: a comprehensive diagnostic tool that helps automate website assurance, which Savage now says he couldn't live without.

\n

It is not only spelling errors that are costing businesses money, as a comprehensive three-year study by Stanford University's Technology Lab points out. After interviewing over 4,500 people about what they thought constituted a credible website, they compiled 10 guidelines to help webmasters ensure the credibility of their websites.

\n

One of the guidelines advises businesses to avoid website errors of all types, no matter how small they seem, as typos, errors and broken links hurt a site's credibility more than most people imagine. Of course, avoiding all errors may seem impossible, but quality software tools can assist in making the job much more manageable.

\n

Another sore point for businesses and customers alike is ensuring private information stays just that - private. Now while most of us probably aren't harboring sensitive information a la WikiLeaks , the fact remains that there is a need to protect information. Especially when we consider damning figures collected by the Open Security Foundation, a non-profit organization, that showed that in only a nine-month period 37 organizations had lost almost 132 million sensitive records through external hacks and poor maintenance work.

\n

Make sure people are laughing with you, and not at you by quality assuring your site.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Shane Diffily

\n
Shane has more than 14 years’ experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance (“The Website Manager’s Handbook”), Shane has also been published by A List Apart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For lots of FREE Web Governance downloads, visit www.diffily.com.
\n
\nFind me on:\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Learning From Web Governance Anarchy In The U.K

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n9/2/14 9:59 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Have you ever heard the expression "democracy is a precious ambrosia carried around in the rusty bucket of human endeavor"?

\n

Well, rarely has that bucket been more rusty than when applied to governmental web governance.

\n

Experience shows that after lots of initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many official sites quickly go into decline.

\n

The problem is that creating a website is now a box-ticking exercise - characterized by poorly understood goals and inadequate support.

\n

Thankfully, that is starting to change. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792151443:\n\n\n\n\n\nDo a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nDo a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792153423:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nThe Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n\n
\n
\n

In my next 3 blog posts I will cover websites and accessibility from a role-based standpoint: Web designers, web developers and web editors. This first contribution is meant for web designers, and gives concrete tips on how to create an accessible web design.

\n
\n

Include the remaining 20% of users

\n

Surveys show that up to 20% of web users are affected by accessibility issues when surfing the web. By following the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines you ensure that as many people as possible can use your website.  We've selected the following criteria as the most relevant for you as a web designer:

\n

Consistent design

\n

Some users may not be accustomed to using the Internet at all, and other users may have a disability that makes it hard to get an overview of a webpage or navigate a website. Therefore, it's important that the navigation is consistent across all your web pages, and global elements like menus and help facilities are in the same order across the site. It's also important that elements with the same function (such as icons and references) are ordered in the same way on every page ( Success criteria 3.2.3 and Success criteria 3.2.4).

\n

Navigation

\n

In order to make it easy for users to find information it's important to have more than one way of finding specific content on a web page. A user can find content on a page by navigating through the intended page hierarchy, but it should also be possible to find the page in another way through a sitemap, an index or a search function ( Success criteria 2.4.5).

\n

Headings

\n

When designing the look and feel and the architecture of a website, it's important to keep in mind that some users cannot get a visual overview of a web page. They have to do this structurally. Make sure pages are divided into logical sections each having a heading (coded as an <h> tag) describing the content, so that assistive technologies can render them as section headings ( Success criteria 1.3.1 and Success criteria 2.4.6).

\n

Use of color

\n

In order to make sure that all users are aware that an element on a web page has a certain function or status, it is important not to give information solely by the use of color. For users who cannot see colors, that information can be lost. An example of conveying information through colors could be to show links within a text by giving links a different color than the text. Supplement this with another non-color specific way of indicating the links (such as underline, a symbol etc.) ( Success criteria 1.4.1).

\n

In order for visually impaired users to be able to read all the text on web pages it is important that the color of the text and the color of the background are in sufficient contrast to each other. This can be ensured by conforming to the requirement of keeping a contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for regular text and 3:1 for large text. There are a number of tools available to quickly assist in measuring the contrast ratios ( Success criteria 1.4.3).

\n

Links

\n

When an element on a web page is to be a link or something clickable, it's important that the element text/description makes sense when read out of context. Part of this is ensured by the technical implementation but the design should consider using descriptive link texts also. Link texts such as: 'Read more,' 'here,' 'Click here,' and 'publication' are examples of poor link text if read out of their context ( Success criteria 2.4.4).

\n

Interactive elements

\n

When designing for interactive elements, i.e. content that the user can interact with, there should be a clear explanation of what is to be entered/chosen/checked. The design should make sure that when text fields, drop downs, check boxes and radio buttons are used, they have text connected to them describing their purpose ( Success criterion 2.4.6 and Success criterion 3.3.2).

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792131603:\n\n\n\n\n\n13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

\n13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n10/17/12 3:46 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n\n
\n

One of the main principles of accessibility optimization is to ensure platform independence, which ensures the website is usable on many different platforms. If you ensure that your website is conforming to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, you will find that your accessibility for mobile devices is ensured to a large extent as well.

\n

A number of principles are relevant when using best practices for web accessibility on mobile platforms. Here are 13 tips on how to fix the most common problems faced by mobile web users.

\n

Design

\n

1. Layout

\n

Design in a way that makes the website work when users can only see a small part of the screen at a time, when they are browsing with mobile units. Some disabled users use zooming software to help them read the page, which creates the same issues imposed by the small screen on many smart phones. Avoid a situation where the user has to scroll both vertically and horizontally, and avoid images that are larger than the screen.

\n

2. Use of color

\n

It is important to avoid creating features or giving information solely based on the user's ability to see colors. Some users are unable to see or differentiate between certain colors. It's also important to make sure the contrast between the background and the text is sufficiently high.

\n

Also, make sure to avoid giving instructions that are color-dependent. (A color-dependent way of giving instructions can be to write: "click on the green button" or "in the blue box to your right you will find more information". If these kinds of descriptions are used make sure to supplement them with a text reference also, such as: 'click on the green button labeled 'Send' or ''in the blue box to your right with the heading 'Events' you will find more information").

\n

Development

\n

3. Following standards

\n

Make sure to follow the standards on the format which you have chosen to publish in. Having clean, validated code helps to ensure that the content is shown in a consistent manner across different platforms and enabling assistive technologies to render content in a meaningful way to users.

\n

4. Order of content

\n

Make sure content is wrapped in a sensible way and that content makes sense from the document order and when linearized. This ensures the content order is meaningful regardless of how the user accesses it and how much CSS is supported by their device.

\n

Tables commonly don't work well on small screens. Consider if there is an alternative way to give tabular content.

\n

5. Navigation

\n

Make sure links and forms are navigable when tabbing through content.

\n

6. Plugins

\n

Avoid making it required for users to install plugins to be able to use content. There might be situations where these are not supported or do not work with certain types of assistive technologies a user might need.

\n

7. Sound and warnings

\n

Avoid giving warnings and other significant information by the use of sound, Some users are not able to hear this either because of a hearing impairment or because of a situation such as being in a location with background noise that makes it hard to hear.

\n

8. Entering data

\n

It may be difficult for some users to enter information by the use of the limited keyboard available on a mobile unit. Make sure to use radio buttons, check boxes and combo boxes when user input is needed. This way, users have to enter as little text as possible via the keyboard.

\n

When users are entering data, make sure to prompt them and help them when they make mistakes. Make sure to technically do this in a way that ensures that it works with voice over and the likes.

\n

9. Page titles

\n

Give each web page a meaningful, short descriptive title. This helps users to ensure that they are on the right page.

\n

Communications

\n

10. Links

\n

Make sure all links have a text or a description that makes sense also when read out of context. Some users navigate between links and for this reason they are dependent on the link text indicating what the link is for.

\n

11. Words and sentences

\n

Avoid complicated words and long sentences. These are not very well suited to mobile units and they complicate things unnecessarily for people with reading difficulties.

\n

12. Subtitles

\n

Multimedia content such as video and sound must be provided with subtitles. In this way people who cannot hear and people with lots of background noise will still be able to understand the content.

\n

13. Images and alternatives

\n

Make sure that when content is non-text, such as images, it has a text alternative. This way users who cannot see and users who have disabled images on their mobile devices can still use the content. Avoid using CSS image replacement and make sure not to use images of text.

\n

More information

\n

W3C has developed a set of documents describing how to best create web content for mobile units and apps for mobile units. You can also read more on how these are connected to the web content accessibility guidelines. They are connected from to different starting points: If you would like to learn more about web accessibility on mobile units or if your starting point is web accessibility and you need to learn more on mobile units.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792136413:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n\n

What Does Google Want?

\n

With their Hummingbird update (released in Sept 2013), Google made a definitive statement about what they want to be. They no longer want to provide search results evenly across companies and industries. Google wants to be an information broker. They want to provide users with the best quality content; content that is relevant to the search and is most likely to satisfy the user’s needs.

\n

What Google wants now is high quality content. Feed Google what it wants, or they will eat you instead.

\n

How Does Google Find High Quality Content?

\n

The Hummingbird update presents a shift from keywords & link building, to content relevance and connections through:

\n

Entities & Co-Occurrences

\n

An Entity is the term used to describe the most commonly searched content- People, places, things, and ideas. Google wants to present the most crucial information that it can about these entities, that’s why the new search results will pull a range of news stories, bios, facts and statistics, and images. The goal is to answer any question you could possibly have.

\n

A Co-Occurrence (or Co-Citation) refers to the shared relationships between Entities across unique websites. Obviously, more relationships will result in a higher search ranking.

\n

Co-Occurrence works like this:

\n

\n

Site A links to Site B and Site C, however Site B and Site C do not link to one another. Google will still imply a relationship between the two, given their shared relationship with Site A.

\n

The more QUALITY, RELEVANT sites that you are able to form relationships with, the more Co-Occurrences Google will be able to identify, and the higher your search rankings will become.

\n

What Does This Mean For Your SEO?

\n

Basically, it means you can’t fool Google anymore. Their robots are faster, smarter, and WAY better at searching the internet than you are. There are over 950 million unique websites on the Internet, and Google has read them all. More than once. Today.

\n

Don’t worry, this is all GOOD NEWS for those who are creating useful, relevant content. So long as you are consistently publishing information, news, articles, or studies that people are searching for, the search engine gods will look upon you favorably.

\n

How Can You Improve Your SEO Now?

\n

Improve your content

\n

This goes without saying. If you’re not putting out quality content, you’ll be ignored by people and robots alike. Make it useful, informative, and easy to consume.

\n

Become an entity

\n

This is what we meant by, “Give Google what it wants.” – i.e. contact information, images, news stories, and biographies. Putting this information on your website, social media pages (especially Google+), and blog will provide Google with more sources and more reason to increase your rankings.

\n

Build relationships

\n

This is where QUALITY outbound links will come into play. By linking to reputable sites with relevant content (e.g. Universities linking to a scholarly journal) you’re telling Google that your site is interested in providing reliable information. If reputable sites take notice and begin linking back to you, that’s a double whammy!

\n

Spoiler alert: Google will give preferential treatment to those who link to their other channels. So if you have a YouTube channel or Google+ page, be sure to create and share relevant content across your channels.

\n

Make your site easy for search engines to crawl

\n

By properly structuring and tagging your site’s HTML, search engine crawlers will be able to easily identify the content on your page. Luckily for you, Google, Bing, and Yahoo! got together back in 2011 to create Schema.org. The goal behind Schema.org was to create a unified set of “schema”, or HTML tags, for webmasters to use when marking up sections of HTML code.

\n

Using the schema/HTML tags found on Schema.org will ensure that you are playing in the same sandbox as the world’s biggest search engines.

\n

 

\n

For more help on crafting useful content that people need, robots want, and your business will benefit from, download our on-demand webinar. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n

 

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792142393:\n\n\n\n\n\nKevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nKevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\n
\n

1. Semantic page markup

\n

Semantic Markup is a way of organizing code so that a browser (or assistive device) can do more of the work interpreting the page. When working with markup languages, it’s important for the code to be semantic by using tags, structure, and information that can be read and translated by all browsers or machines.

\n

Accessibility enables people with disabilities to use your site. Semantic code is usually more accessible. When you properly label your pages with titles, headings, paragraphs, and lists, you make it easier for screen readers and other assistive technologies to read and present the content in a form that a disabled person can understand. Please note the emphasis on the word usually. Semantic HTML is not a total solution to make your site compliant with accessibility guidelines, but it certainly makes building accessible sites easier.

\n

2. Consistent navigation

\n

People with disabilities use navigation features to familiarize themselves with web pages and use them to navigate around web sites. Frequently, they use navigation structures as a roadmap or signpost—a way of placing themselves within page content. By using consistent navigation, you are ensuring that users with disabilities can quickly navigate through a complex web page.

\n

3. Keyboard navigation

\n

Ensuring keyboard access to a site allows people who cannot use a mouse or another pointing device to utilize the site. Additionally, a person who cannot see the screen and relies on a screen reader may have no problem moving a mouse, but will be unable to tell where the mouse is pointed.

\n

Assigning an access key, or keyboard short cut, to a link can provide a useful way for users to access the link. When the mouse can activate an element, then it should also be capable of being activated by the keyboard. For example, a person with a disability that affects dexterity may find it impossible to move or hold a pointing device with enough accuracy to initiate desired features.

\n

The tab order of elements on the page should follow a logical progression on the page, and take into account the purpose of the page. When the tabindex attribute is used but not applied to all controls, the tab order can become inconsistent, which can make filling out forms or navigating through the page extremely difficult.

\n

4. Skip Navigation

\n

Pages with repetitive groups of links need a way for a user to skip past them, so that they can get to the page's main content as efficiently as possible. When style sheets (CSS) are turned off the skip link anchor should still be visible.

\n

Consider a keyboard-only user’s visit to a website that uses a top navigation bar on all of its pages. Each time the user navigates to a new page within the site, the user would be forced to tab through all of these navigation links, and other content, before getting to the main content area of the page. This makes it difficult to access the page's unique information efficiently.

\n

5. Color

\n

Color should not be used as the only way to communicate information. There are usually two solutions to this issue. One is to provide an alternative text equivalent, another is to make on-screen text or style changes to the content.

\n

Text alternatives are useful to those without vision. However, these alternatives are challenging for people who cannot see color, or when content is displayed without color. Some browsers do not show alternative text for images, and if the browser does, it requires the user to mouse over the image.

\n

Graphs and charts are notoriously difficult to understand for people with disabilities, because they rely so heavily on colors. Textures or patterns may be helpful for communicating information that usually relies on color. Color should not be the sole method of designating a link within non-linked text. The use of underlining or other font styles can assist with navigation for everyone.

\n

This does not mean you shouldn’t use color to enhance important features, but it does however require that some other system of identification, such as on-screen text, is combined with the use of color.

\n

6. Page titles

\n

The title of a page needs to provide information specific to the current page. Assistive technologies use the page title to signify the current page location to users without having to navigate around on the page. Assistive technology often reads the page title first, so the title should inform the user of the content to be found, or the action to be performed on that page.

\n

7. Heading tags

\n

Heading elements should be used only when necessary, and to indicate the beginning of related ‘chunks’ of content. Making good use of headings can deliver a great benefit to users of assistive technology by providing the user with a way to navigate section-by-section through content. By using headings incorrectly, or for passages of text that do not define a section, assistive technology users may not be able to take advantage of this useful navigation technique.

\n

Section headings should also be used to organize content in documents. Section headings simplify navigation, and help users comprehend the way the document is organized. When documents are not organized using section headings, some users with learning disabilities may not be able to understand the organization of content. And some users who are visually impaired may not be able to quickly skim and navigate to locations on the page. Quick navigation keys used to navigate by heading with screen readers will not be available.

\n

8. Tables

\n

The role of data tables is to present information in a grid, and to have column or rows that show the meaning of the information in the grid. When screen readers read straight through data tables—especially large ones—it's easy for users to get lost.

\n

In order for a data table to be accessible, it must have the proper markup. When the proper HTML markup is in place on a data table, users of screen readers can navigate through one cell at a time, and they will hear the column and row headers spoken to them. The very first step toward creating an accessible data table is to designate row and/or column headers. This is easy to do—most authoring tools provide a method of changing data cells into header cells. In the markup, the <td> tag is used for table data cells and the <th> tag is used for table header cells.

\n

Tables should have some sort of title or caption to them. It is not absolutely necessary to have captions on every data table for accessibility, but it is still a good practice.

\n

Developers should utilize CSS to define the layout of the page. Using tables to create the page layout can keep the pages from rendering properly. This is especially true on pages that use complex layouts.

\n

9. Forms labels

\n

Fields that are laid out in a non-intuitive order are difficult for users to utilize, whether they use assistive technology or not. Developers should ensure that the keyboard focus order matches the implied visual order of the form elements.

\n

Form fields must be clearly associated with on-screen labels when present. When on-screen labels are not present, form fields must be given an accessible label. When form fields do not include a label, assistive technology may guess at the label or provide no label at all to users. When labels are present, users of assistive technology are much more likely to complete a form.

\n

10. “Click here” text

\n

The W3C's Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.0) recommend against the use of phrases such as "click here" as link text. "Link text should not be overly general, and should indicate the nature of the link target". The text should also make sense when read out of context.

\n

“Click here” also implies the user is using a mouse to navigate. Screen readers may review a list of available links, and a phrase like “click here” will offer no value or clear pathway for the user. Such phrases may also negatively affect search engine optimization.

\n

It’s important to note that many times these types of link text are generated automatically from different blogging or news publishing software and may take a little more effort to correct. Your developer should be able to help adjust this text.

\n

When calling a user to action try to follow these link guidelines:

\n
    \n
  • Provide some information when the link is read out of context
    • \n
  • Explain what the link offers the user
    • \n
  • Don’t talk about mechanics
    • \n
  • Is not a verb phrase
    • \n
\n

For more information, visit the Tips for Webmasters section of the W3C Quality Assurance website.

\n

\n \n \n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

  • \nJanuary 2013 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nDecember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nNovember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nOctober 2012 (5)\n
    • \n

  • \nJuly 2012 (4)\n

  • \nJune 2012 (4)\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792147693:\n\n\n\n\n\n The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

\n The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\n
\n

1. Not exploring beyond the default setting

\n

All Analytics tools come with pre-set options and settings right out of the box. While it’s easier to stick with these default settings, they may not yield the information you want. Depending on the type of tool you use, a deep product understanding may be required to ensure correct implementation. Most reputable analytic tools will have a team of experienced consultants available to help you make the right choice. Never underestimate the effect specialized setting can have for your data.

\n

Recommendation: Get assistance setting up your analytics, as it can make the difference between success and failure.

\n

2. Not having a script on every page

\n

The golden rule of analytics is to ensure there is a script on every single page - yet all too often particular pages are forgotten. Usually this occurs because certain pages aren’t part of the default template for many CMSs. Pages typically lacking scripts are onsite search results pages, campaign pages, sub-domains and 404 error pages. It’s especially important that 404 pages aren’t forgotten, since without the script you won’t be able to find the source of the error – be it an internal or external one.

\n

People often wonder if it’s possible to just put a script on certain pages to save money with their paid solution. The answer is a resounding “no, it will destroy your data.” Instead, you are better off investing in an affordable tool that meets your traffic needs.  

\n

Recommendation: Invest in the regular use of a site audit tool that can scan your site for pages without an analytics script.

\n

3. Not excluding URL Parameters  

\n

Parameters can be useful, but if not properly utilized within an analytics system they can also become a hindrance. In order to help you best understand and interpret your analytics data, it is essential that you decide which parameters to exclude and which to include. If this decision is not actively undertaken you will undoubtedly end up with confusing masses of data, and in many cases, a skewed view. 

\n

When deciding whether you can exclude a parameter or not you should ask yourself two questions:

\n

1. Will the content on the page change if the parameter is removed?
2. Will the content on the page change if the value of the parameter is changed?

If you can answer “no” to both questions, then you probably can exclude the parameter and get cleaner data.

\n

Recommendation: List all used parameters, and decide which to exclude from the analytics data.

\n

4. Forgetting to exclude internal IP addresses

\n

Using IP exclusion to exclude internal employee website use from analytics data is highly recommended, as is regularly updating the internal list of IP addresses. Typically, this filter is set up during the implementation phase and is then forgotten about. Changes like adopting a new IT infrastructure or getting a new IP address are often overlooked, causing a false spike to show up in the website traffic.

\n

Recommendation: Inform the responsible person or department for IP creations and modifications of the existence of an Analytics IP file and establish a routine for updating this.

\n

5. Overlooking on-site search fields

\n

Tracking the “site search” section of a website is essential so you know what your users are looking for. There are multiple ways to do this that depend on which CMS and Analytics tool you use, but it can also make you susceptible to tracking errors.

\n

Typically, three errors become apparent:

\n

1) There is no tracking script on the results page that people reach, as this is typically not part of the default template. This means that you potentially do not know what people are searching for the second time they search.

\n

2) The search terms and number of results are tracked via parameters in the URL and these do not change with a repeated search, which again results in lost data the second time someone searches.

\n

3) There are two search boxes on the search results page: the permanent search box that appears in the upper right corner of every page on the website, and a large center box unique to the search results page . Both of these search boxes must have specific site search tracking, otherwise you’ll lose searches.

\n

Errors regarding onsite search are some of the most difficult to see in reports, and once you’ve lost that valuable knowledge regarding search it’s gone forever.

\n

Recommendation: Test that site search tracking works and that repeated searches are also tracked properly. Additionally, ensure that all search boxes are tested and when used in different combinations they render data.

\n

6. Event tracking - Be proactive, and think ahead when giving names.

\n

You should always set up event tracking for those relevant elements on your site that don’t trigger a page view, this may include videos for example. This is important to set up in the beginning as this data cannot be recreated on historical data.

\n

The hardest and most important part of event tracking is defining a syntax for the naming of a category, action and label that is workable, future-proof and logical. Once you have chosen a name you should document it somewhere, such as an excel sheet, where all used combinations are added so that you always have a reference of the correct naming. One last important detail is that you must be 100% consistent in the terms you use. From the beginning, it is essential to decide what actions performed on your site will be called and to ensure that you keep this naming consistent across all pages. For example: if a certain action is called “expand” on your home page and that action is repeated elsewhere on the site, it should also be called “expand” there rather than “click” or “open.”  

Recommendation: When beginning to track events, go that extra mile and it will pay off in the future. Take the time to define a workable, future proof and logical naming procedure and follow it consistently. Document implemented event tracking and be sure to including the naming.

\n

7. Campaign tracking - be consistent

\n

Campaign tracking is an extremely important way to gain insight into which campaigns drive traffic to your site. The only thing worse than not undertaking campaign tracking is half-hearted campaign tracking. You must collect data consistently to give a true and fair view that can actually be used to evaluate campaigns.

\n

Campaign tracking naming is similar to event tracking, and the naming recommendations are the same. Remember that mediums such as “email,” “e-mail” and “mail,” will not be grouped together and this cannot be changed once the error has been made.

\n

A typical source of error in campaign tracking is using a campaign URL to redirect without forwarding the campaign parameters to the original link. This can come from a 302 redirect or a news email provider that has changed links in emails.

\n

Recommendation: Use campaign tracking consistently, be careful with the naming and test your links when using redirects.

\n

8. The mother of all web analytics sins

\n

Last and most important, the mother of all web analytics sins: Failing to have an analytics professional associated with your business who has mastered your analytics tool AND has enough insight into your Business Goals to support them by contributing relevant, reliable and valid data. Almost all other sins can be traced back to this sin.

\n

Leave the sinners life behind

\n

Understanding analytics data can seem difficult but with the right set-up and support it can provide you and others in your organization with the key information needed to make smart decisions – be it for your marketing, sales or IT teams. For those who already use an analytics tool it may be a great time to take a step back and check whether it’s working as intended, and for those embarking on the journey hopefully this has provided a solid foundation on which to grow your knowledge.

\n

So please remember that just because your analytics data looks reliable, it’s not necessary valid. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792150733:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWhy Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\n

The lack of accessibility of online documents exposes website owners to the same risks as inaccessible web pages. Although we could address many different online documents such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, our focus will be on the predominant format, PDF (Portable Document Format).

\n

Q: What defines an Accessible Document?

\n

A: A document is considered accessible if all users, with or without disabilities, can read and understand all the information it contains.  Every user should be able to:

\n
    \n
  • Understand the document’s structure
    • \n
  • Read and understand the document’s contents, including text and images
    • \n
  • Understand and navigate sections such as tables
    • \n
  • Interact with any forms
    • \n
\n

Assistive technology is only as good as the information you provide to it. If you don’t provide good instructions, the technology isn’t able to do its job. Providing accessible instructions (tagged documents) ensures that assistive technology can accomplish its purpose. Remember that there are also different levels of accessibility—not accessible, partly accessible, and fully accessible. How you build your documents will determine these levels.

\n

Q: What Are the Document’s Accessibility Standards?

\n

A: It’s important to use the most relevant standard for any given technology, and online documents are no different. Here is how these different standards affect online documents:

\n

WCAG 2.0

\n

WCAG 2.0 applies to web content. Although PDF is not recognized by the W3C as a standard web format, PDF use on websites is addressed by 23 different WCAG PDF Techniques including:

\n
    \n
  • PDF1: Applying text alternatives to images (Success Criterion 1.1.1, Non-text content)
    • \n
  • PDF3: Ensuring correct tab and reading order in PDF documents (Success Criterion 1.3.2, Meaningful Sequence)
    • \n
  • PDF9: Providing headings (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
  • PDF11: Providing links and link text (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
  • PDF16: Setting the default language (Success Criterion 3.1.1, Language of Page)
    • \n
  • PDF21: Using List tags for lists in PDF documents (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
\n

The PDF techniques will be covered in detail in a future blog post. In the mean time, which standard is considered the formal document standard for PDF files?

\n

PDF/UA (ISO 14289)

\n

PDF/UA is not a different file format, but a technique to implement the PDF format. The reason for PDF/UA (ISO 14289) is to describe how to create electronic documents in the PDF format in a way that allows the file to be accessible. The accessibility is dependent on semantic information in a document. Semantic information may also include additional metadata, like alternative text for images.

\n

Matterhorn Protocol

\n

To promote use of PDF/UA, the PDF Association’s PDF/UA Competence Center created the Matterhorn Protocol. The Matterhorn Protocol is a group of 31 checkpoints that includes 136 failure points corresponding to PDF/UA’s file format requirements.

\n

Just because a document passes PDF/UA compliance doesn’t mean it will pass the WCAG, and organizations shouldn’t treat PDF/UA as a WCAG replacement, but utilize both standards.

\n

Q: How Do Search Engines Handle PDFs?

\n

A: In the past search engines were not able to index PDF content, but that’s no longer the case; search engine technology is now able to gather much of the information provided in a document. The difference between web pages and PDF pages is that web pages are optimized for search engines. Many PDFs contain detailed information, and search engines love that detailed information. Properly tagged PDFs will enhance the indexing of the document, and make that detailed information much more valuable.

\n

Q: When Should I Use PDF files?

\n

Appropriate Uses of PDF Files

\n
    \n
  • Secure documents
    • \n
  • Downloadable documents
    • \n
  • Print documents that need to keep formatting
    • \n
  • Documents that provide more detail
    • \n
  • Interactive forms
    • \n
  • Low usage documents (large documents, archives)
    • \n
\n

Remember these insights:

\n
    \n
  • HTML achieves accessibility better than PDF
    • \n
  • Most PDFs on the web should be HTML
    • \n
  • Many websites have a print to PDF feature
    • \n
  • Some documents (Word, Excel, etc.), should be PDFs
    • \n
\n

Who is responsible for making the PDF accessible?

\n

Training

\n

Document content producers are usually different from your Web content producers. You will need to modify your training accordingly. Train producers on the appropriate techniques to save tagged PDFs.

\n

Templates

\n

Provide template files that meet both accessibility and branding guidelines. Move forward with new documents—make them accessible. Don’t try and convert all of your old files right away, convert them on an as-needed basis.

\n

Remediation

\n

Once you have created accessible templates for distribution, think about how you will update existing documents. Here are a few things to consider:

\n
    \n
  • Will you be providing accessible documents on an “as needed” basis?
    • \n
  • How often do you need to provide an accessible document?
    • \n
  • What is your turn-around time for providing an accessible document?
    • \n
  • Do you need to engage an outside provider to assist with document remediation?
    • \n
\n

Q: Where Do I Start?

\n

A: We’re offering a free webinar on getting started with document accessibility. The webinar is a valuable way to understand why your documents need to be accessible. We’ll discuss:

\n
    \n
  • What is an Accessible Document?
    • \n
  • Accessible Document Standards
    • \n
  • PDFs and Search Engines
    • \n
  • When to provide PDFs online
    • \n
  • Who is responsible for PDF accessibility?
    • \n
\n

We will then follow up with webinars on creating accessible documents in Word and InDesign.

\n

Sign up for our webinar, “Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important” here.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n

\n6/24/13 2:25 AM\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites ...

\n
\nRead More\n

CONFAB 2013 Minneapolis Roundup

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/12/13 2:33 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Creation' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/16/13 4:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n
